speaker: Doctor
text: So you're experiencing decreased vision and seeing black spots in your right eye. Can you tell me when these symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about 2 days ago. I was watching TV and suddenly everything got blurry, and I saw these dark spots moving around in my right eye."

speaker: Doctor
text: How would you describe the black spots you're seeing - are they moving or stationary, and do they affect your entire field of vision in your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're moving, kind of floating around. It's like they're dancing in my eye. They don't seem to be affecting my entire field of vision, but if I try to focus on something, they get in the way."

speaker: Doctor
text: The black spots started about 2 weeks ago, but they've been getting worse over time. How would you describe the color of these black spots - are they purely black or do they have any other hue to them?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're more like a dark gray, almost a charcoal color. It's like someone's drawn a charcoal pencil in my eye, and it's just sitting there."

speaker: Doctor
text: They're purely black, no other color to them. Have you experienced any pain or pressure in your right eye, or is it just a sudden onset of these black spots?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't feel any pain or pressure in my right eye. It's just this... this stuff in my eye, and it's really annoying because it's making it hard for me to see."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that you've been experiencing these symptoms for a couple of weeks now. Have you noticed any changes in your eye movements or difficulty tracking objects with your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been a bit harder to track objects with my right eye, especially if they're moving quickly. It's like my eye is having trouble keeping up, but when I try to focus on something, it seems to get a bit better for a second before the black spots come back in the way."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent eye injuries or trauma to your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, nothing like that. I don't recall hitting my eye or anything like that. It just started out of nowhere, like I said."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any other symptoms besides decreased vision and black spots in your right eye, such as fever, headaches, or sensitivity to light?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't have a fever or any headaches. But I do have to admit, I've been feeling a bit more fatigued than usual lately. It's like I'm running on low battery, and I just want to sleep all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you have a history of AIDS, which puts you at a higher risk for certain eye infections. Can you tell me if you've been taking your antiretroviral medication regularly and if you've noticed any changes in your immune system lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been taking my meds regularly, I think. I mean, I take Efavirenz, Tenofovir, and Emtricitabine every day, and I also take Azithromycin and Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for my Kaposi's sarcoma. But to be honest, I haven't been feeling like my usual self lately. I get tired easily, and I've been getting sick more often."

speaker: Doctor
text: You've been taking your antiretroviral medication regularly, that's good to hear. However, the fact that you have AIDS does increase your risk for certain eye infections. Have you experienced any unusual discharge or redness in your right eye?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, there's no discharge or redness in my right eye. It just looks normal, but with these... things floating around in it."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that you've been taking your medication regularly, which is a good sign. Have you noticed any changes in your vision or eye movements when you're under stress or after a long period of time?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've noticed that when I'm really stressed out or I've been up all night, my vision seems to get worse. It's like my eye is already tired, and then it gets even more tired when I'm stressed. And yeah, after a long period of time, my vision does seem to get a bit worse too."

speaker: Doctor
text: So you've been taking your antiretroviral medication regularly and haven't noticed any changes in your immune system lately. Have you had any recent contact with anyone who has a similar eye infection, or any travel history to areas where certain eye infections are more common?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I haven't had any contact with anyone who has a similar eye infection, and I haven't traveled anywhere recently. I've been pretty much stuck at home lately, just trying to take care of myself."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent changes in your appetite or weight since starting antiretroviral medication, and do you have any other underlying medical conditions besides AIDS that I should be aware of?

speaker: Patient
text:
"I've had a bit of a decrease in my appetite lately, to be honest. It's hard to eat when you're feeling tired all the time. And as for my weight, I've actually lost a bit of weight since starting my meds. I'm not sure if it's because of the meds or just because I'm not eating as much, but yeah, I've lost a few pounds."

"I do have a history of fungal esophagitis, which I was treated for 6 months ago. I'm not sure if that's relevant to my current situation, but I thought it was worth mentioning."

speaker: Doctor
text: So you haven't noticed any unusual discharge or redness in your right eye, but your history of AIDS does increase your risk for certain eye infections. Have you had any recent vision tests or eye exams that might give us some insight into what's going on with your vision?

speaker: Patient
text: "I had a routine eye exam about 6 months ago, before I started noticing these... things in my eye. The doctor said my vision was fine, but I don't think they were looking for anything like this. I mean, I wasn't complaining about my vision back then, just my stomach problems with the fungal esophagitis."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any vision problems or eye issues before this current episode, or is this the first time you've had any issues with your vision?

speaker: Patient
text: "This is the first time I've had any issues with my vision like this. I've had some problems with my stomach, like I mentioned before, but I've never had any trouble with my eyes before. At least, not until now, when it feels like my right eye is just... cloudy, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had no previous vision problems before this episode, which makes me a bit more concerned. Have you ever experienced any eye floaters or flashes of light in your right eye before the black spots started?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think I've ever experienced eye floaters or flashes of light in my right eye before. It's just been this... this stuff in my eye, and it's been really frustrating because it's making it hard for me to see. I feel like I'm trying to look through a foggy window or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that you've been taking your antiretroviral medication regularly, but I have to ask, have you noticed any changes in your CD4 count lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "To be honest, I'm not even sure what a CD4 count is. My doctor just tells me to take my meds and come back for check-ups. I don't really understand what's going on with my immune system, but I'm trying to follow my treatment plan as best I can."

speaker: Doctor
text: You've been taking your antiretroviral medication regularly and haven't noticed any changes in your immune system lately. Have you experienced any recent difficulty with walking or balance, or any dizziness that might be related to your vision problems?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, to be honest, I have been having a bit of trouble with my balance lately. It's like I'm stumbling over my own feet or something. I'm not sure if it's related to my vision problems, but it's definitely been making me feel a bit more unsteady than usual."

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had no previous vision problems, that's helpful to know. Have you experienced any blurred vision or double vision in your right eye, and if so, how long have you been experiencing these symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've had some blurred vision in my right eye, but I'm not sure how long it's been going on. I think it started around the same time I noticed the black spots. And as for double vision, I'm not sure if I've experienced that exactly, but it's like my eye is having trouble focusing on things. Sometimes I'll look at something and it'll seem like it's wobbling back and forth."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your right eye more closely. Can you look up and to the right for me, so I can get a better view of the affected area?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'll try my best, but it's a bit hard to focus with these... things in my eye. I'll do my best to look up and to the right for you."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've examined your right eye and I notice that the pupils are reacting normally, but I do see some retinal changes that are concerning. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I'm going to take a deep breath and make a diagnosis. 

DIAGNOSIS READY: CMV Retinitis 

CMV retinitis is a serious eye infection that can cause vision loss and is common in people with weakened immune systems, such as those with AIDS. It's often associated with retinal changes, which is what I've observed in your right eye. I'm going to recommend treatment with antiviral medication to manage the infection and prevent further vision loss.
